column4:
Write a composition of at least 150 words on what you can do to make a difference.

.
column5:
It was a sunny Sunday morning , the sun shone brillantly in the clear blue sky . Sarah jumped out of bed and got ready to go out. She ran down the stairs and quikly devoured her breakfast ." Mom , let's go ! " Sarah exclaimed . Sarah's Mother had promised Sarah that they would get to adopt a dog today . Sarah had saved up money from the previous yer and will be using it to adopt a dog . 
 Once they reached the adopting centre , Sarah and her mother were greeted with barks . Sarah skipped down the aisle of dog and look at each of them but none of the dogs seem to be catching her attention . Soon, Sarah noticed a dog that caught her attention . It had brown fur , it's eyes were big and round and it was very skinny . The dog stared at Sarah as though asking her to take it home . 
 Sarah deceied to take the dog home. She placed her savings on the counter to pay. From that day onwards Sarah took great care of the dog.
column6: Provide subtle hints or clues without giving direct answers, allowing students to arrive at the correct answer on their own.
column9:
Adjective - Incorrect or inappropriate use of adjectives, such as using the wrong form (comparative, superlative): Incorrect: "She is more prettier than her sister." Correct: "She is prettier than her sister.",

Adverb - Incorrect use of adverbs, such as using an adjective instead of an adverb: Incorrect: "He runs quick." Correct: "He runs quickly.",

Capitalisation/ case - Incorrect use of uppercase and lowercase letters, especially for proper nouns and sentence beginnings: Incorrect: "i went to paris last summer." Correct: "I went to Paris last summer.",

Collocation - Incorrect pairing of words that do not naturally go together in English: Incorrect: "She made a big effort." Correct: "She made a great effort.",

Conjunction - Incorrect use or omission of conjunctions to link sentences or clauses. Incorrect: "Although it was cold outside, but I still went for a walk." Correct: "Although it was cold outside, I still went for a walk.",

Contraction - Incorrect use or omission of contractions, leading to confusion: Incorrect: "Its raining today." Correct: "It’s raining today.",

Determiner - Incorrect use or omission of determiners, such as articles, quantifiers and possessive determiners (e.g., a, an, the, much, many, my, your). Incorrect: "I love the nature." Correct: "I love nature.",

Noun - Incorrect noun forms, including pluralisation or uncountable nouns: Incorrect: "I have many homeworks." Correct: "I have a lot of homework.",

Other - Miscellaneous errors that don’t fit other categories: Incorrect: "I enjoy to the fullest life." Correct: "I enjoy life to the fullest.",

Particle - Incorrect use of particles, especially in phrasal verbs. Incorrect: "Please fill the form before leaving." Correct: "Please fill out the form before leaving.",

Possessive - Incorrect use of possessive forms (’s or s’). Incorrect: "The dog wagged it's tail." Correct: "The dog wagged its tail.",

Preposition - Incorrect or missing prepositions, leading to grammatical errors: Incorrect: "She is good in math." Correct: "She is good at math.",

Pronoun - Incorrect pronoun usage, including unclear references or agreement issues. Incorrect: "Each student must bring their book." Correct: "Each student must bring his or her book.",

Punctuation - Incorrect or missing punctuation marks that change the meaning. Incorrect: "Let’s eat Grandma." Correct: "Let’s eat, Grandma.",

Sentence - Errors related to sentence structure, such as fragments or run-ons: Incorrect: "When I arrived. I saw him." Correct: "When I arrived, I saw him.",

Space - Missing or extra spaces between words or punctuation: Incorrect: "I went tothe park." Correct: "I went to the park.",

Spelling - Incorrect spelling of words, affecting comprehension: Incorrect: "She recieved a letter." Correct: "She received a letter.",

Verb - Incorrect verb tense, agreement, or form (including gerunds/infinitives). Incorrect: "I look forward to meet you." Correct: "I look forward to meeting you.",

Word choice - Using an incorrect or suboptimal word that does not fit the context. Incorrect: "He is a criminal who has alluded capture." Correct: "He is a criminal who has eluded capture.",

Word order - Incorrect word order, making sentences sound unnatural or confusing: Incorrect: "She always is late." Correct: "She is always late."

column4:
Write a composition of at least 150 words on what you can do to make a difference.

.
column5:
It was a sunny Sunday morning , the sun shone brillantly in the clear blue sky . Sarah jumped out of bed and got ready to go out. She ran down the stairs and quikly devoured her breakfast ." Mom , let's go ! " Sarah exclaimed . Sarah's Mother had promised Sarah that they would get to adopt a dog today . Sarah had saved up money from the previous yer and will be using it to adopt a dog . 
 Once they reached the adopting centre , Sarah and her mother were greeted with barks . Sarah skipped down the aisle of dog and look at each of them but none of the dogs seem to be catching her attention . Soon, Sarah noticed a dog that caught her attention . It had brown fur , it's eyes were big and round and it was very skinny . The dog stared at Sarah as though asking her to take it home . 
 Sarah deceied to take the dog home. She placed her savings on the counter to pay. From that day onwards Sarah took great care of the dog.

column4:
Refer to your essay plan which already outlines what 'you want to tell me' and write an introduction for your essay. 
[Recap] Your introduction should: 
  • have an opening that attracts the attention and interest of readers
  • address the keywords so that your reader knows how you are defining the terms [e.g., what does a competitive environment in school look like? What does something that is desirable (or not) look like? What makes it desirable (or not?)]
  • Outline the scope using your topic sentences 
  • State your thesis Statement which is your overall stand
You may refer to the attached essay plan with a sample introduction you can model after.
.
column5: \nIn our rapidly developing society, a child's future is often regarded as the top priority of parents. Many parents hope their children have bright and sustainable futures, and this is often only possible when students ace their examinations. As Singapore is a meritocratic society, only the top percentile can attain the best standard of education. As such, parents often push their children to strive for better grades. However, this pursuit would lead to a highly competitive learning environment where, on one hand, students would find themselves in such an overwhelming learning environment, leading to students having excessive stress and mental strain. Likewise, parents may disapprove of such an overly competitive learning environment, fearing that it might promote an unhealthy perception of education. Meanwhile, governments view competition in schools as a way to find and nurture national talent. Similarly, tuition companies may support a competitive education system, as it motivates worrisome parents to seek extra academic support, ultimately boosting their business. While it is clear that unhealthy competition can be harmful to students, a well-managed and positive competitive environment can motivate learners and bring out their full potential. Therefore, when implemented strategically, competition in schools can be beneficial.\n
column6: Get the student to reflect on whether they followed the required and correct processes to arrive at the answer, such as if they have read and understood the question, the process errors they made that caused them to write an inaccurate or incomplete description. If the student's response is lacking, provide a clear, actionable step for them to improve.

column5: \nIn our rapidly developing society, a child's future is often regarded as the top priority of parents. While it is clear that unhealthy competition can be harmful to students, a well-managed and positive competitive environment can motivate learners and bring out their full potential. Many parents hope their children have bright and sustainable futures, and this is often only possible when students ace their examinations. As Singapore is a meritocratic society, only the top percentile can attain the best standard of education. As such, parents often push their children to strive for better grades. However, this pursuit would lead to a highly competitive learning environment where, on one hand, students would find themselves in such an overwhelming learning environment, leading to students having excessive stress and mental strain. Likewise, parents may disapprove of such an overly competitive learning environment, fearing that it might promote an unhealthy perception of education. Meanwhile, governments view competition in schools as a way to find and nurture national talent. Similarly, tuition companies may support a competitive education system, as it motivates worrisome parents to seek extra academic support, ultimately boosting their business. While it is clear that unhealthy competition can be harmful to students, a well-managed and positive competitive environment can motivate learners and bring out their full potential. Therefore, when implemented strategically, competition in schools can be beneficial.\n
column6: Get the student to reflect on whether they followed the required and correct processes to arrive at the answer, such as if they have read and understood the question, the process errors they made that caused them to write an inaccurate or incomplete description. If the student's response is lacking, provide a clear, actionable step for them to improve.
column9:
Adjective - Incorrect or inappropriate use of adjectives, such as using the wrong form (comparative, superlative): Incorrect: "She is more prettier than her sister." Correct: "She is prettier than her sister.",

Adverb - Incorrect use of adverbs, such as using an adjective instead of an adverb: Incorrect: "He runs quick." Correct: "He runs quickly.",

Capitalisation/ case - Incorrect use of uppercase and lowercase letters, especially for proper nouns and sentence beginnings: Incorrect: "i went to paris last summer." Correct: "I went to Paris last summer.",

Collocation - Incorrect pairing of words that do not naturally go together in English: Incorrect: "She made a big effort." Correct: "She made a great effort.",

Conjunction - Incorrect use or omission of conjunctions to link sentences or clauses. Incorrect: "Although it was cold outside, but I still went for a walk." Correct: "Although it was cold outside, I still went for a walk.",

Contraction - Incorrect use or omission of contractions, leading to confusion: Incorrect: "Its raining today." Correct: "It’s raining today.",

Determiner - Incorrect use or omission of determiners, such as articles, quantifiers and possessive determiners (e.g., a, an, the, much, many, my, your). Incorrect: "I love the nature." Correct: "I love nature.",

Noun - Incorrect noun forms, including pluralisation or uncountable nouns: Incorrect: "I have many homeworks." Correct: "I have a lot of homework.",

Other - Miscellaneous errors that don’t fit other categories: Incorrect: "I enjoy to the fullest life." Correct: "I enjoy life to the fullest.",

Particle - Incorrect use of particles, especially in phrasal verbs. Incorrect: "Please fill the form before leaving." Correct: "Please fill out the form before leaving.",

Possessive - Incorrect use of possessive forms (’s or s’). Incorrect: "The dog wagged it's tail." Correct: "The dog wagged its tail.",

Preposition - Incorrect or missing prepositions, leading to grammatical errors: Incorrect: "She is good in math." Correct: "She is good at math.",

Pronoun - Incorrect pronoun usage, including unclear references or agreement issues. Incorrect: "Each student must bring their book." Correct: "Each student must bring his or her book.",

Punctuation - Incorrect or missing punctuation marks that change the meaning. Incorrect: "Let’s eat Grandma." Correct: "Let’s eat, Grandma.",

Sentence - Errors related to sentence structure, such as fragments or run-ons: Incorrect: "When I arrived. I saw him." Correct: "When I arrived, I saw him.",

Space - Missing or extra spaces between words or punctuation: Incorrect: "I went tothe park." Correct: "I went to the park.",

Spelling - Incorrect spelling of words, affecting comprehension: Incorrect: "She recieved a letter." Correct: "She received a letter.",

Verb - Incorrect verb tense, agreement, or form (including gerunds/infinitives). Incorrect: "I look forward to meet you." Correct: "I look forward to meeting you.",

Word choice - Using an incorrect or suboptimal word that does not fit the context. Incorrect: "He is a criminal who has alluded capture." Correct: "He is a criminal who has eluded capture.",

Word order - Incorrect word order, making sentences sound unnatural or confusing: Incorrect: "She always is late." Correct: "She is always late."

column4:
Refer to your essay plan which already outlines what 'you want to tell me' and write an introduction for your essay. 
[Recap] Your introduction should: 
  • have an opening that attracts the attention and interest of readers
  • address the keywords so that your reader knows how you are defining the terms [e.g., what does a competitive environment in school look like? What does something that is desirable (or not) look like? What makes it desirable (or not?)]
  • Outline the scope using your topic sentences 
  • State your thesis Statement which is your overall stand
You may refer to the attached essay plan with a sample introduction you can model after.
.

column4:
Write a composition of at least 150 words about overcoming fear.
The pictures are provided to help you think about this topic. Your composition should be based on one or more of these pictures.
 
 
Consider the following points when you plan your composition:
  • What were you afraid of?
  • Why were you afraid of it?
  • How did you overcome your fear?
 
You may use the points in any order and include other relevant points as well.
.
column5:
I have always been afraid of Dobermanns. Their sharp teeth,strong bodies,and dark eyes made them look dangerous. Whenever I saw one, my stomach twisted, and I wanted to run in the other direction.

 One day, I decided I did not want to be afraid anymore. My bestfriend, Olivia, had a Dobermann puppy named Crunchy." He is very friendly,"Olivia said."Come and meet him."I felt nervous, but I agreed.

 That afternoon, as I stepped outside, I suddenly heard loud barking. I looked up and froze. A man was walking past with a large Dobermann on a lead. It fixed its sharp eyes on me and led out a deep,booming bark that echoed through the streets. My whole body tensed. My hands turned clammy , and my heart pounded against my chest.

 "Stay calm...do not run..."I told myself, but my legs trembled, ready to bolt. I gripped the hen of my shirt tightly, my mind racing. What if it chased me? What if it bit me? The dog took a step forward, ears perked. I swallowed hard, my breath coming in short, I panicked gasps.

 Then, I remembered why I was here. I had to face my fear. Slowly, I took a deep breath and stepped forward, my heart still beating a little too fast. The Dobermann sat calmly in front of me, its bark eyes watched me curiously. I hesitated, then stretched out my hand.

 The dog sniffed my fingers before pressing its cold, wet nose against my palm. A shaky smile spread across my face as I exhaled, the tension in my shoulders easing ."You are not so scary after all,"I whispered, stroking its sleek fur.

 A wave of warmth filled my chest. I had faced my fear, and it no longer controlled me.

  • Why were you afraid of it?

.
column5:
I have always been afraid of Dobermanns. Their sharp teeth,strong bodies,and dark eyes made them look dangerous. Whenever I saw one, my stomach twisted, and I wanted to run in the other direction.

 One day, I decided I did not want to be afraid anymore. My bestfriend, Olivia, had a Dobermann puppy named Crunchy." He is very friendly,"Olivia said."Come and meet him."I felt nervous, but I agreed.

 That afternoon, as I stepped outside, I suddenly heard loud barking. I looked up and froze. A man was walking past with a large Dobermann on a lead. It fixed its sharp eyes on me and led out a deep,booming bark that echoed through the streets. My whole body tensed. My hands turned clammy , and my heart pounded against my chest.

 "Stay calm...do not run..."I told myself, but my legs trembled, ready to bolt. I gripped the hen of my shirt tightly, my mind racing. What if it chased me? What if it bit me? The dog took a step forward, ears perked. I swallowed hard, my breath coming in short, I panicked gasps.

 Then, I remembered why I was here. I had to face my fear. Slowly, I took a deep breath and stepped forward, my heart still beating a little too fast. The Dobermann sat calmly in front of me, its bark eyes watched me curiously. I hesitated, then stretched out my hand.

 The dog sniffed my fingers before pressing its cold, wet nose against my palm. A shaky smile spread across my face as I exhaled, the tension in my shoulders easing ."You are not so scary after all,"I whispered, stroking its sleek fur.

 A wave of warmth filled my chest. I had faced my fear, and it no longer controlled me.

Conjunction - Incorrect use or omission of conjunctions to link sentences or clauses. Incorrect: "Although it was cold outside, but I still went for a walk." Correct: "Although it was cold outside, I still went for a walk.",

Contraction - Incorrect use or omission of contractions, leading to confusion: Incorrect: "Its raining today." Correct: "It’s raining today.",

Determiner - Incorrect use or omission of determiners, such as articles, quantifiers and possessive determiners (e.g., a, an, the, much, many, my, your). Incorrect: "I love the nature." Correct: "I love nature.",

Noun - Incorrect noun forms, including pluralisation or uncountable nouns: Incorrect: "I have many homeworks." Correct: "I have a lot of homework.",

Other - Miscellaneous errors that don’t fit other categories: Incorrect: "I enjoy to the fullest life." Correct: "I enjoy life to the fullest.",

Particle - Incorrect use of particles, especially in phrasal verbs. Incorrect: "Please fill the form before leaving." Correct: "Please fill out the form before leaving.",

Possessive - Incorrect use of possessive forms (’s or s’). Incorrect: "The dog wagged it's tail." Correct: "The dog wagged its tail.",

Preposition - Incorrect or missing prepositions, leading to grammatical errors: Incorrect: "She is good in math." Correct: "She is good at math.",

Pronoun - Incorrect pronoun usage, including unclear references or agreement issues. Incorrect: "Each student must bring their book." Correct: "Each student must bring his or her book.",

Punctuation - Incorrect or missing punctuation marks that change the meaning. Incorrect: "Let’s eat Grandma." Correct: "Let’s eat, Grandma.",

Sentence - Errors related to sentence structure, such as fragments or run-ons: Incorrect: "When I arrived. I saw him." Correct: "When I arrived, I saw him.",

Space - Missing or extra spaces between words or punctuation: Incorrect: "I went tothe park." Correct: "I went to the park.",

Spelling - Incorrect spelling of words, affecting comprehension: Incorrect: "She recieved a letter." Correct: "She received a letter.",

Verb - Incorrect verb tense, agreement, or form (including gerunds/infinitives). Incorrect: "I look forward to meet you." Correct: "I look forward to meeting you.",

Word choice - Using an incorrect or suboptimal word that does not fit the context. Incorrect: "He is a criminal who has alluded capture." Correct: "He is a criminal who has eluded capture.",

Word order - Incorrect word order, making sentences sound unnatural or confusing: Incorrect: "She always is late." Correct: "She is always late."

column5:
“Where has my parrot gone?” Amy, Dan’s older sister, exclaimed frantically. It was just after dinner and Amy had returned to her bedroom to feed her parrot only to find the cage open, empty and had a single red feather from her parrot inside it. “Oh no!” She thought, “My parents are not going to let me keep a pet ever again if I don’t find out who did it!” 
 Instantaneously, she sprung into action to try and find out who did it. First, she thought that she might not have locked the cage properly due to her carelessness but recalled clearly that she did lock the cage. Then, she started looking around the cage to see if there were any clues left behind by the culprit. Meanwhile, her younger brother had heard her shout. Waves of anxiety swept through him as he was the one who had set the bird free as he was watching and feeding it without his sister’s permission. At the birdcage, Amy found a piece of cloth with red and white stripes on it that looked like it had been torn off a shirt. She pondered whether the cloth could have been torn off the culprit’s shirt when they freed the bird.
 However, she could not rule anyone out yet as everyone in the family all had red and white striped shirts to wear on national day and they all had tears on them due to various accidents that happened. Below the cage, she found a packet of half-empty bird seeds as if someone was feeding the parrot before it escaped and also an overturned stool. She thought that it might have been her brother as he was the only one who needed a stool to unlock the cage but realised that it could not be him as he did not have the key to unlock the cage. 
 Amy then thought to check the security camera her parents had installed and noticed that there was a person standing near the cage at around 7 o'clock at night. She zoomed in on the figure and discovered that the person was short and standing near the cage. Although she could not see what he or she was doing, there was a loud squawk soon afterwards as the parrot escaped.
 Then, realisation dawned on Amy as she hurried to the place where she kept the keys and discovered the key was missing and there was only the spare key left. Realising her own brother had done it, she stormed up the stairs furiously and slammed open her brother’s bedroom door. When Amy opened the door, the waves of rage in her was palpable as she accused her brother indignantly, “I knew you let my parrot escape!” “I… I didn't do it!” Dan said shakily. “Yes you did! There was a piece of the cloth that you are wearing now and also a stool which you used to steal my keys!” Amy said angrily. “I am going to tell mom and dad!”
 The anxiety that coursed through Dan like a wave was palpable as he stuttered over his words. He did set the parrot free but only accidentally as he wanted to feed it at least once.
 In the end, Amy’s parents ordered Dan to pay back the money used to buy the parrot out of his own pocket money and apologize to Amy. She forgave him and decided to put this incident aside and let bygones be bygones.

Collocation - Incorrect pairing of words that do not naturally go together in English: Incorrect: "She made a big effort." Correct: "She made a great effort.",

Conjunction - Incorrect use or omission of conjunctions to link sentences or clauses. Incorrect: "Although it was cold outside, but I still went for a walk." Correct: "Although it was cold outside, I still went for a walk.",

Contraction - Incorrect use or omission of contractions, leading to confusion: Incorrect: "Its raining today." Correct: "It’s raining today.",

Determiner - Incorrect use or omission of determiners, such as articles, quantifiers and possessive determiners (e.g., a, an, the, much, many, my, your). Incorrect: "I love the nature." Correct: "I love nature.",

Noun - Incorrect noun forms, including pluralisation or uncountable nouns: Incorrect: "I have many homeworks." Correct: "I have a lot of homework.",

Other - Miscellaneous errors that don’t fit other categories: Incorrect: "I enjoy to the fullest life." Correct: "I enjoy life to the fullest.",

Particle - Incorrect use of particles, especially in phrasal verbs. Incorrect: "Please fill the form before leaving." Correct: "Please fill out the form before leaving.",

Possessive - Incorrect use of possessive forms (’s or s’). Incorrect: "The dog wagged it's tail." Correct: "The dog wagged its tail.",

Preposition - Incorrect or missing prepositions, leading to grammatical errors: Incorrect: "She is good in math." Correct: "She is good at math.",

Pronoun - Incorrect pronoun usage, including unclear references or agreement issues. Incorrect: "Each student must bring their book." Correct: "Each student must bring his or her book.",

Punctuation - Incorrect or missing punctuation marks that change the meaning. Incorrect: "Let’s eat Grandma." Correct: "Let’s eat, Grandma.",

Sentence - Errors related to sentence structure, such as fragments or run-ons: Incorrect: "When I arrived. I saw him." Correct: "When I arrived, I saw him.",

Space - Missing or extra spaces between words or punctuation: Incorrect: "I went tothe park." Correct: "I went to the park.",

Spelling - Incorrect spelling of words, affecting comprehension: Incorrect: "She recieved a letter." Correct: "She received a letter.",

Verb - Incorrect verb tense, agreement, or form (including gerunds/infinitives). Incorrect: "I look forward to meet you." Correct: "I look forward to meeting you.",

Word choice - Using an incorrect or suboptimal word that does not fit the context. Incorrect: "He is a criminal who has alluded capture." Correct: "He is a criminal who has eluded capture.",

Word order - Incorrect word order, making sentences sound unnatural or confusing: Incorrect: "She always is late." Correct: "She is always late."

column5:
“Where has my parrot gone?” Amy, Dan’s older sister, exclaimed frantically. It was just after dinner and Amy had returned to her bedroom to feed her parrot only to find the cage open, empty and had a single red feather from her parrot inside it. “Oh no!” She thought, “My parents are not going to let me keep a pet ever again if I don’t find out who did it!” 
 Instantaneously, she sprung into action to try and find out who did it. First, she thought that she might not have locked the cage properly due to her carelessness but recalled clearly that she did lock the cage. Then, she started looking around the cage to see if there were any clues left behind by the culprit. Meanwhile, her younger brother had heard her shout. Waves of anxiety swept through him as he was the one who had set the bird free as he was watching and feeding it without his sister’s permission. At the birdcage, Amy found a piece of cloth with red and white stripes on it that looked like it had been torn off a shirt. She pondered whether the cloth could have been torn off the culprit’s shirt when they freed the bird.
 However, she could not rule anyone out yet as everyone in the family all had red and white striped shirts to wear on national day and they all had tears on them due to various accidents that happened. Below the cage, she found a packet of half-empty bird seeds as if someone was feeding the parrot before it escaped and also an overturned stool. She thought that it might have been her brother as he was the only one who needed a stool to unlock the cage but realised that it could not be him as he did not have the key to unlock the cage. 
 Amy then thought to check the security camera her parents had installed and noticed that there was a person standing near the cage at around 7 o'clock at night. She zoomed in on the figure and discovered that the person was short and standing near the cage. Although she could not see what he or she was doing, there was a loud squawk soon afterwards as the parrot escaped.
 Then, realisation dawned on Amy as she hurried to the place where she kept the keys and discovered the key was missing and there was only the spare key left. Realising her own brother had done it, she stormed up the stairs furiously and slammed open her brother’s bedroom door. When Amy opened the door, the waves of rage in her was palpable as she accused her brother indignantly, “I knew you let my parrot escape!” “I… I didn't do it!” Dan said shakily. “Yes you did! There was a piece of the cloth that you are wearing now and also a stool which you used to steal my keys!” Amy said angrily. “I am going to tell mom and dad!”
 The anxiety that coursed through Dan like a wave was palpable as he stuttered over his words. He did set the parrot free but only accidentally as he wanted to feed it at least once.
 In the end, Amy’s parents ordered Dan to pay back the money used to buy the parrot out of his own pocket money and apologize to Amy. She forgave him and decided to put this incident aside and let bygones be bygones.

column4:
Introduction

\n
Type the introduction of your Draft 1 - An Encouragement.

column5: At home, I was lying down in bed and stared blankly at the ceiling. At the corner of my eye, I saw a photograph that caught my attention. I got up and walked to it, upon taking a look at the photograph, I saw me holding a test paper with full marks. I thought about it, but I could not recall anything. As I walked back to my bed, I suddenly recalled the moment in the photograph and the momories came flashing back\n

column4:
After reading and viewing your classmates’ responses, write a new paragraph of about 50 words in response to this prompt:
 
Bullies deserve a chance to become better people. Do you agree? Why, or why not?
.
column5: No, not everyone can deserve a second chance for what they did especially if it has damaged someones life for no good reason. Bullies often just do the work they are needed to do for their actions but they dont learn from it. If they have caused harm to someones life trying to be \"cool\" or \"impress\" people they should not be given a second chance as it is not fair to the person who got bullied. If they truely changed and feel regret and guilt they should first make up to the person they bullied and prevent others from facing the same thing. That truely shoes that they care\n

column4:
After reading and viewing your classmates’ responses, write a new paragraph of about 50 words in response to this prompt:
 
Bullies deserve a chance to become better people. Do you agree? Why, or why not?
.
column5: No, not everyone can deserve a second chance for what they did especially if it has damaged someones life for no good reason. Bullies often just do the work they are needed to do for their actions but they dont learn from it. If they have caused harm to someones life trying to be \"cool\" or \"impress\" people they should not be given a second chance as it is not fair to the person who got bullied. If they truely changed and feel regret and guilt they should first make up to the person they bullied and prevent others from facing the same thing. That truely shoes that they care\n

column4:
What two pieces of information does the writer give to suggest that the burglar was caught in the end?
.\n
column5: They mentioned that the next afternoon was a friday, and the ladies gathered again to discuss about what to wear during ceremony where the police would be presenting each of them with a good Neighnout Award.\n

column4:
作者的篮球是怎么不见的？（5分）

.\n
column5: 作者把篮球借给子平。子平练完球后把球旅放在球场,去子一趟洗手间,回不回平后就没看到篮球了,他还以为是作者拿回去。\n
column6: Make it easy for young learners to understand by avoiding complex words and shortening sentences, but do not reveal the answer.

.\n

column5:
One sunny afternoon Kevin and caleb went out to the playground and play. they were having fun playing in the playground . 

As caleb and kevin was about to go to the toilet they saw a lonely boy siting down in the pavement crying . kevin ask caleb "why is he crying ? shall we go ask him why is he crying?. caleb said "ok come lets go." . They went to the boy and ask "dear boy why are you sitting in the pavement alone and crying ? " .The boy said " when i was playing in the play playground I was thirsty so i wanted to go to my parents to drink some water as i was going my parents was not there i was so scared i tried searching for them but i could not find them instead i waited over here and see if they came." kevin said " ok don't worry me and my friend caleb will help you find you parents."

 Kevin ,caleb and the boy was searching for the boy's parents they were searching up and down left and right but stil no sign no sign of them .The boy was hoping when will he find his parents .when they when back to the playground there was no sign of them .As the boy turned right alas they found his parents he ran to his parents and hugged them so tight.The boy's parents found the two boys and said thank you to them the two boys was so happy that they helped someone in need .
column6: Provide specific text replacement for students to improve the text.

column4:
为什么来听小黄鸟唱歌的动物越来越少了？（2分）
.\n
column5: 因为她每天唱同一首歌，大家听久了就不觉得好听了。只要她学唱新歌，小动物就会再来听她唱歌了。” \n
column6: Underline ”因为“ if the students included them. If not, hint them to do so.

column4:
请写一篇不少过100个字的作文。作文的题目是《发生在上学路上的一件事》。

.\n
column5:
一天早晨，我赶着去上学。天色还是黑色的，风非常大。我只顾这低头往前走。走着走着，我看见两位男孩穿蓝的衣服和黑色的短裤，他们高兴的在路边提着球。
两位男孩高兴地踢着球，但是过了一会儿，以为男孩没抓好球，球就却滚到大马路上。一位男孩上前往前走去捡球起来但是他没看见前面的车。
 
幸好，那位男孩没有被车撞到。我看了到了这件事，就对两位男孩说：“你们不应该在马路边踢球，这样非常危险！”两位男孩听了后，就马上点点了头，离开了。
column6: Provide specific text replacement for students to improve the text. Generate in Chinese.

column4:
请写一篇不少过100个字的作文。作文的题目是《发生在上学路上的一件事》。

.\n
column5:
一天早晨，我赶着去上学。天色还是黑色的，风非常大。我只顾这低头往前走。走着走着，我看见两位男孩穿蓝的衣服和黑色的短裤，他们高兴的在路边提着球。
两位男孩高兴地踢着球，但是过了一会儿，以为男孩没抓好球，球就却滚到大马路上。一位男孩上前往前走去捡球起来但是他没看见前面的车。
 
幸好，那位男孩没有被车撞到。我看了到了这件事，就对两位男孩说：“你们不应该在马路边踢球，这样非常危险！”两位男孩听了后，就马上点点了头，离开了。

column4:
Write a composition of at least 150 words on what you can do to make a difference.

.
column5:
It was a sunny Sunday morning , the sun shone brillantly in the clear blue sky . Sarah jumped out of bed and got ready to go out. She ran down the stairs and quikly devoured her breakfast ." Mom , let's go ! " Sarah exclaimed . Sarah's Mother had promised Sarah that they would get to adopt a dog today . Sarah had saved up money from the previous yer and will be using it to adopt a dog . 
 Once they reached the adopting centre , Sarah and her mother were greeted with barks . Sarah skipped down the aisle of dog and look at each of them but none of the dogs seem to be catching her attention . Soon, Sarah noticed a dog that caught her attention . It had brown fur , it's eyes were big and round and it was very skinny . The dog stared at Sarah as though asking her to take it home . 
 Sarah deceied to take the dog home. She placed her savings on the counter to pay. From that day onwards Sarah took great care of the dog.

column4:
提供段落：
 
        一天早上，小明和大华在课室里玩篮球。他们把球抛来抛去，玩得非常开心。这时，黄老师朝课室走了过来……
 
.
column5:
一天早上，小明和大华在课室里玩篮球。他们把球抛来抛去，玩得非常开心。这时，黄老师朝课室走了过来。
 小明和大华从窗户里瞄到了黄老师，他们大吃一惊，把球扔到过道里，以迅雷不及掩耳之速从后门跑了出去。“哎哟！”一个小朋友痛苦叫道，没想到那个”从天而降的球“居然不长眼睛打到了一个小朋友，鼻血从鼻子里流了出来，滴到了她的衣服上，把一块衣服染成红色。当小明和大华正向趁黄老师不注意时溜走，没想到还是被发现了。
 “给我过来！“黄老师严厉地喊道。小明和大华走了过来，低着头，不敢直视老师的眼光。”你们怎么能用篮球打同学呢，就算你是不小心的，也不应该不到钱就溜走啊！"老师严厉的训斥道。“我们没有，对不对小明！”大华理直气壮地狡辩道，“对......对的吧。“小明结结巴巴地说道。”这是不是你的球，居然拿到教室里来胡作非为!"黄老师平静的说道，心里想着：希望他们承认错误，我还是不会骂他的。“没有，根本没有，我以偷篮球的技术来担保，啊呸呸呸，我有证人，那就是小明！”大华一口气说道。“对......对吧。“小明结结巴巴地说道。老师故意没说，却说”那么你们当时在不在玩这个篮球呢？“黄老师服满疑问的问道。”没有，就算有一百个摄像头看着我，也不可能会发现一点证据呢！”大华再一次的狡辩道。“嗯......没有吧。“小明又结结巴巴地说道。“真的，我再问一遍，这是不是你的球，居然拿到教室里来胡作非为！你们当时在不在玩这个篮球呢？你承认我就不会骂你，也不会责怪你的！“黄老师平静地说，但是小明和大华一一摇头。大华坚决地摇头，但是小明只是微微摇头，不过还带了点颤抖。
 黄老师没办法，只好先送哪位小朋友到医务室，接着带着大华和小明上到四楼。”我们要去哪里呀？“小明问道，“我也不知道。“大华回答道，他们转过一个又一个走廊终于到达了，房间外的字使他们毛骨悚然，而那字是”校长室“。黄老师没有直接带他们进去，却又问了一遍之前的问题”这是不是你的球，居然拿到教室里来，你们当时在不在玩这个篮球吗？“ 这次大华居然畏畏缩缩地说”这......这个球是我从体育库里偷......偷来的，当时是......是在跟小明玩球。“
 黄老师平静地说到”你们承认了错误，值得表扬，我可以原谅你们，但是你们所做的行为是不能宽恕的，你们这一周都不能再课间休息时玩。“，”知道了！我们保证下一次不会再犯同样的错误了。“小明和大华异口同声地说道。接着，老师让他们回去，他们回到教室，跟那个打到的小朋友说了道歉，一后再也没有偷过东西，也没有在教室里玩了。
 所谓”前事不忘，后事之师。“以后我们做错了事，要承认错误，这样能受到原谅。但是我们不能一而三再而三的犯了，不能做一个屡教不改的孩子哦！

column4:
提供段落：
 
        一天早上，小明和大华在课室里玩篮球。他们把球抛来抛去，玩得非常开心。这时，黄老师朝课室走了过来……
 
.
column5:
一天早上，小明和大华在课室里玩篮球。他们把球抛来抛去，玩得非常开心。这时，黄老师朝课室走了过来。
 小明和大华从窗户里瞄到了黄老师，他们大吃一惊，把球扔到过道里，以迅雷不及掩耳之速从后门跑了出去。“哎哟！”一个小朋友痛苦叫道，没想到那个”从天而降的球“居然不长眼睛打到了一个小朋友，鼻血从鼻子里流了出来，滴到了她的衣服上，把一块衣服染成红色。当小明和大华正向趁黄老师不注意时溜走，没想到还是被发现了。
 “给我过来！“黄老师严厉地喊道。小明和大华走了过来，低着头，不敢直视老师的眼光。”你们怎么能用篮球打同学呢，就算你是不小心的，也不应该不到钱就溜走啊！"老师严厉的训斥道。“我们没有，对不对小明！”大华理直气壮地狡辩道，“对......对的吧。“小明结结巴巴地说道。”这是不是你的球，居然拿到教室里来胡作非为!"黄老师平静的说道，心里想着：希望他们承认错误，我还是不会骂他的。“没有，根本没有，我以偷篮球的技术来担保，啊呸呸呸，我有证人，那就是小明！”大华一口气说道。“对......对吧。“小明结结巴巴地说道。老师故意没说，却说”那么你们当时在不在玩这个篮球呢？“黄老师服满疑问的问道。”没有，就算有一百个摄像头看着我，也不可能会发现一点证据呢！”大华再一次的狡辩道。“嗯......没有吧。“小明又结结巴巴地说道。“真的，我再问一遍，这是不是你的球，居然拿到教室里来胡作非为！你们当时在不在玩这个篮球呢？你承认我就不会骂你，也不会责怪你的！“黄老师平静地说，但是小明和大华一一摇头。大华坚决地摇头，但是小明只是微微摇头，不过还带了点颤抖。
 黄老师没办法，只好先送哪位小朋友到医务室，接着带着大华和小明上到四楼。”我们要去哪里呀？“小明问道，“我也不知道。“大华回答道，他们转过一个又一个走廊终于到达了，房间外的字使他们毛骨悚然，而那字是”校长室“。黄老师没有直接带他们进去，却又问了一遍之前的问题”这是不是你的球，居然拿到教室里来，你们当时在不在玩这个篮球吗？“ 这次大华居然畏畏缩缩地说”这......这个球是我从体育库里偷......偷来的，当时是......是在跟小明玩球。“
 黄老师平静地说到”你们承认了错误，值得表扬，我可以原谅你们，但是你们所做的行为是不能宽恕的，你们这一周都不能再课间休息时玩。“，”知道了！我们保证下一次不会再犯同样的错误了。“小明和大华异口同声地说道。接着，老师让他们回去，他们回到教室，跟那个打到的小朋友说了道歉，一后再也没有偷过东西，也没有在教室里玩了。
 所谓”前事不忘，后事之师。“以后我们做错了事，要承认错误，这样能受到原谅。但是我们不能一而三再而三的犯了，不能做一个屡教不改的孩子哦！

column4:
提供段落：
 
        一天早上，小明和大华在课室里玩篮球。他们把球抛来抛去，玩得非常开心。这时，黄老师朝课室走了过来……
 
.
column5:
一天早上，小明和大华在课室里玩篮球。他们把球抛来抛去，玩得非常开心。这时，黄老师朝课室走了过来。
 小明和大华从窗户里瞄到了黄老师，他们大吃一惊，把球扔到过道里，以迅雷不及掩耳之速从后门跑了出去。“哎哟！”一个小朋友痛苦叫道，没想到那个”从天而降的球“居然不长眼睛打到了一个小朋友，鼻血从鼻子里流了出来，滴到了她的衣服上，把一块衣服染成红色。当小明和大华正向趁黄老师不注意时溜走，没想到还是被发现了。
 “给我过来！“黄老师严厉地喊道。小明和大华走了过来，低着头，不敢直视老师的眼光。”你们怎么能用篮球打同学呢，就算你是不小心的，也不应该不到钱就溜走啊！"老师严厉的训斥道。“我们没有，对不对小明！”大华理直气壮地狡辩道，“对......对的吧。“小明结结巴巴地说道。”这是不是你的球，居然拿到教室里来胡作非为!"黄老师平静的说道，心里想着：希望他们承认错误，我还是不会骂他的。“没有，根本没有，我以偷篮球的技术来担保，啊呸呸呸，我有证人，那就是小明！”大华一口气说道。“对......对吧。“小明结结巴巴地说道。老师故意没说，却说”那么你们当时在不在玩这个篮球呢？“黄老师服满疑问的问道。”没有，就算有一百个摄像头看着我，也不可能会发现一点证据呢！”大华再一次的狡辩道。“嗯......没有吧。“小明又结结巴巴地说道。“真的，我再问一遍，这是不是你的球，居然拿到教室里来胡作非为！你们当时在不在玩这个篮球呢？你承认我就不会骂你，也不会责怪你的！“黄老师平静地说，但是小明和大华一一摇头。大华坚决地摇头，但是小明只是微微摇头，不过还带了点颤抖。
 黄老师没办法，只好先送哪位小朋友到医务室，接着带着大华和小明上到四楼。”我们要去哪里呀？“小明问道，“我也不知道。“大华回答道，他们转过一个又一个走廊终于到达了，房间外的字使他们毛骨悚然，而那字是”校长室“。黄老师没有直接带他们进去，却又问了一遍之前的问题”这是不是你的球，居然拿到教室里来，你们当时在不在玩这个篮球吗？“ 这次大华居然畏畏缩缩地说”这......这个球是我从体育库里偷......偷来的，当时是......是在跟小明玩球。“
 黄老师平静地说到”你们承认了错误，值得表扬，我可以原谅你们，但是你们所做的行为是不能宽恕的，你们这一周都不能再课间休息时玩。“，”知道了！我们保证下一次不会再犯同样的错误了。“小明和大华异口同声地说道。接着，老师让他们回去，他们回到教室，跟那个打到的小朋友说了道歉，一后再也没有偷过东西，也没有在教室里玩了。
 所谓”前事不忘，后事之师。“以后我们做错了事，要承认错误，这样能受到原谅。但是我们不能一而三再而三的犯了，不能做一个屡教不改的孩子哦！
column6: Provide subtle hints or clues without giving direct answers, allowing students to arrive at the correct answer on their own.

一天早上，小明和大华在课室里玩篮球。他们把球抛来抛去，玩得非常开心。这时，黄老师朝课室走了过来。
 小明和大华从窗户里瞄到了黄老师，他们大吃一惊，把球扔到过道里，以迅雷不及掩耳之速从后门跑了出去。“哎哟！”一个小朋友痛苦叫道，没想到那个”从天而降的球“居然不长眼睛打到了一个小朋友，鼻血从鼻子里流了出来，滴到了她的衣服上，把一块衣服染成红色。当小明和大华正向趁黄老师不注意时溜走，没想到还是被发现了。
 “给我过来！“黄老师严厉地喊道。小明和大华走了过来，低着头，不敢直视老师的眼光。”你们怎么能用篮球打同学呢，就算你是不小心的，也不应该不到钱就溜走啊！"老师严厉的训斥道。“我们没有，对不对小明！”大华理直气壮地狡辩道，“对......对的吧。“小明结结巴巴地说道。”这是不是你的球，居然拿到教室里来胡作非为!"黄老师平静的说道，心里想着：希望他们承认错误，我还是不会骂他的。“没有，根本没有，我以偷篮球的技术来担保，啊呸呸呸，我有证人，那就是小明！”大华一口气说道。“对......对吧。“小明结结巴巴地说道。老师故意没说，却说”那么你们当时在不在玩这个篮球呢？“黄老师服满疑问的问道。”没有，就算有一百个摄像头看着我，也不可能会发现一点证据呢！”大华再一次的狡辩道。“嗯......没有吧。“小明又结结巴巴地说道。“真的，我再问一遍，这是不是你的球，居然拿到教室里来胡作非为！你们当时在不在玩这个篮球呢？你承认我就不会骂你，也不会责怪你的！“黄老师平静地说，但是小明和大华一一摇头。大华坚决地摇头，但是小明只是微微摇头，不过还带了点颤抖。
 黄老师没办法，只好先送哪位小朋友到医务室，接着带着大华和小明上到四楼。”我们要去哪里呀？“小明问道，“我也不知道。“大华回答道，他们转过一个又一个走廊终于到达了，房间外的字使他们毛骨悚然，而那字是”校长室“。黄老师没有直接带他们进去，却又问了一遍之前的问题”这是不是你的球，居然拿到教室里来，你们当时在不在玩这个篮球吗？“ 这次大华居然畏畏缩缩地说”这......这个球是我从体育库里偷......偷来的，当时是......是在跟小明玩球。“
 黄老师平静地说到”你们承认了错误，值得表扬，我可以原谅你们，但是你们所做的行为是不能宽恕的，你们这一周都不能再课间休息时玩。“，”知道了！我们保证下一次不会再犯同样的错误了。“小明和大华异口同声地说道。接着，老师让他们回去，他们回到教室，跟那个打到的小朋友说了道歉，一后再也没有偷过东西，也没有在教室里玩了。
 所谓”前事不忘，后事之师。“以后我们做错了事，要承认错误，这样能受到原谅。但是我们不能一而三再而三的犯了，不能做一个屡教不改的孩子哦！
column6: Provide subtle hints or clues without giving direct answers, allowing students to arrive at the correct answer on their own.
column8:
内容（10分） （扣紧题目，情节完整，逻辑合理） – 需改进 – 续写内容与开头无关，或者完全偏题，无法看出合理的发展。
逻辑混乱，缺乏完整情节，无法理解事件发展。, 内容（10分） （扣紧题目，情节完整，逻辑合理） – 一般 – 续写部分较偏离主题，或者只是简单描述，没有展开情节。
事件发展缺乏合理性，细节贫乏，结局模糊或不清晰。, 内容（10分） （扣紧题目，情节完整，逻辑合理） – 良好 – 续写情节较简单，与开头有关但不够深入，细节描写较少。
事件发展较单调，高潮不够突出，结局较突兀或缺乏意义。, 内容（10分） （扣紧题目，情节完整，逻辑合理） – 优秀 – 故事情节较完整，基本紧扣课堂玩球，但发展略显平淡或部分细节不足。
叙述有起因、经过、结果，但高潮部分不够突显，影响阅读体验。
结局较合理，但教育意义不够深刻或略显仓促。, 内容（10分） （扣紧题目，情节完整，逻辑合理） – 特优 – 故事情节完整，紧扣小明、大华、黄老师的课堂玩球事件，合理续写发展。
叙述起因（为何玩球）、经过（黄老师发现后如何处理）、高潮（事件的转折点）、结果（最终影响），情节有层次，环环相扣。

column4:
提供段落：
 
        一天早上，小明和大华在课室里玩篮球。他们把球抛来抛去，玩得非常开心。这时，黄老师朝课室走了过来……
 
.
column5:
一天早上，小明和大华在课室里玩篮球。他们把球抛来抛去，玩得非常开心。这时，黄老师朝课室走了过来。
 小明和大华从窗户里瞄到了黄老师，他们大吃一惊，把球扔到过道里，以迅雷不及掩耳之速从后门跑了出去。“哎哟！”一个小朋友痛苦叫道，没想到那个”从天而降的球“居然不长眼睛打到了一个小朋友，鼻血从鼻子里流了出来，滴到了她的衣服上，把一块衣服染成红色。当小明和大华正向趁黄老师不注意时溜走，没想到还是被发现了。
 “给我过来！“黄老师严厉地喊道。小明和大华走了过来，低着头，不敢直视老师的眼光。”你们怎么能用篮球打同学呢，就算你是不小心的，也不应该不到钱就溜走啊！"老师严厉的训斥道。“我们没有，对不对小明！”大华理直气壮地狡辩道，“对......对的吧。“小明结结巴巴地说道。”这是不是你的球，居然拿到教室里来胡作非为!"黄老师平静的说道，心里想着：希望他们承认错误，我还是不会骂他的。“没有，根本没有，我以偷篮球的技术来担保，啊呸呸呸，我有证人，那就是小明！”大华一口气说道。“对......对吧。“小明结结巴巴地说道。老师故意没说，却说”那么你们当时在不在玩这个篮球呢？“黄老师服满疑问的问道。”没有，就算有一百个摄像头看着我，也不可能会发现一点证据呢！”大华再一次的狡辩道。“嗯......没有吧。“小明又结结巴巴地说道。“真的，我再问一遍，这是不是你的球，居然拿到教室里来胡作非为！你们当时在不在玩这个篮球呢？你承认我就不会骂你，也不会责怪你的！“黄老师平静地说，但是小明和大华一一摇头。大华坚决地摇头，但是小明只是微微摇头，不过还带了点颤抖。
 黄老师没办法，只好先送哪位小朋友到医务室，接着带着大华和小明上到四楼。”我们要去哪里呀？“小明问道，“我也不知道。“大华回答道，他们转过一个又一个走廊终于到达了，房间外的字使他们毛骨悚然，而那字是”校长室“。黄老师没有直接带他们进去，却又问了一遍之前的问题”这是不是你的球，居然拿到教室里来，你们当时在不在玩这个篮球吗？“ 这次大华居然畏畏缩缩地说”这......这个球是我从体育库里偷......偷来的，当时是......是在跟小明玩球。“
 黄老师平静地说到”你们承认了错误，值得表扬，我可以原谅你们，但是你们所做的行为是不能宽恕的，你们这一周都不能再课间休息时玩。“，”知道了！我们保证下一次不会再犯同样的错误了。“小明和大华异口同声地说道。接着，老师让他们回去，他们回到教室，跟那个打到的小朋友说了道歉，一后再也没有偷过东西，也没有在教室里玩了。
 所谓”前事不忘，后事之师。“以后我们做错了事，要承认错误，这样能受到原谅。但是我们不能一而三再而三的犯了，不能做一个屡教不改的孩子哦！
column6: Provide subtle hints or clues without giving direct answers, allowing students to arrive at the correct answer on their own.

column4:
提供段落：
 
        一天早上，小明和大华在课室里玩篮球。他们把球抛来抛去，玩得非常开心。这时，黄老师朝课室走了过来……
 
.
column5:
一天早上，小明和大华在课室里玩篮球。他们把球抛来抛去，玩得非常开心。这时，黄老师朝课室走了过来。
 小明和大华从窗户里瞄到了黄老师，他们大吃一惊，把球扔到过道里，以迅雷不及掩耳之速从后门跑了出去。“哎哟！”一个小朋友痛苦叫道，没想到那个”从天而降的球“居然不长眼睛打到了一个小朋友，鼻血从鼻子里流了出来，滴到了她的衣服上，把一块衣服染成红色。当小明和大华正向趁黄老师不注意时溜走，没想到还是被发现了。
 “给我过来！“黄老师严厉地喊道。小明和大华走了过来，低着头，不敢直视老师的眼光。”你们怎么能用篮球打同学呢，就算你是不小心的，也不应该不到钱就溜走啊！"老师严厉的训斥道。“我们没有，对不对小明！”大华理直气壮地狡辩道，“对......对的吧。“小明结结巴巴地说道。”这是不是你的球，居然拿到教室里来胡作非为!"黄老师平静的说道，心里想着：希望他们承认错误，我还是不会骂他的。“没有，根本没有，我以偷篮球的技术来担保，啊呸呸呸，我有证人，那就是小明！”大华一口气说道。“对......对吧。“小明结结巴巴地说道。老师故意没说，却说”那么你们当时在不在玩这个篮球呢？“黄老师服满疑问的问道。”没有，就算有一百个摄像头看着我，也不可能会发现一点证据呢！”大华再一次的狡辩道。“嗯......没有吧。“小明又结结巴巴地说道。“真的，我再问一遍，这是不是你的球，居然拿到教室里来胡作非为！你们当时在不在玩这个篮球呢？你承认我就不会骂你，也不会责怪你的！“黄老师平静地说，但是小明和大华一一摇头。大华坚决地摇头，但是小明只是微微摇头，不过还带了点颤抖。
 黄老师没办法，只好先送哪位小朋友到医务室，接着带着大华和小明上到四楼。”我们要去哪里呀？“小明问道，“我也不知道。“大华回答道，他们转过一个又一个走廊终于到达了，房间外的字使他们毛骨悚然，而那字是”校长室“。黄老师没有直接带他们进去，却又问了一遍之前的问题”这是不是你的球，居然拿到教室里来，你们当时在不在玩这个篮球吗？“ 这次大华居然畏畏缩缩地说”这......这个球是我从体育库里偷......偷来的，当时是......是在跟小明玩球。“
 黄老师平静地说到”你们承认了错误，值得表扬，我可以原谅你们，但是你们所做的行为是不能宽恕的，你们这一周都不能再课间休息时玩。“，”知道了！我们保证下一次不会再犯同样的错误了。“小明和大华异口同声地说道。接着，老师让他们回去，他们回到教室，跟那个打到的小朋友说了道歉，一后再也没有偷过东西，也没有在教室里玩了。
 所谓”前事不忘，后事之师。“以后我们做错了事，要承认错误，这样能受到原谅。但是我们不能一而三再而三的犯了，不能做一个屡教不改的孩子哦！
column6: Provide subtle hints or clues without giving direct answers, allowing students to arrive at the correct answer on their own.

column5:
一天早上，小明和大华在课室里玩篮球。他们把球抛来抛去，玩得非常开心。这时，黄老师朝课室走了过来。
 小明和大华从窗户里瞄到了黄老师，他们大吃一惊，把球扔到过道里，以迅雷不及掩耳之速从后门跑了出去。“哎哟！”一个小朋友痛苦叫道，没想到那个”从天而降的球“居然不长眼睛打到了一个小朋友，鼻血从鼻子里流了出来，滴到了她的衣服上，把一块衣服染成红色。当小明和大华正向趁黄老师不注意时溜走，没想到还是被发现了。
 “给我过来！“黄老师严厉地喊道。小明和大华走了过来，低着头，不敢直视老师的眼光。”你们怎么能用篮球打同学呢，就算你是不小心的，也不应该不到钱就溜走啊！"老师严厉的训斥道。“我们没有，对不对小明！”大华理直气壮地狡辩道，“对......对的吧。“小明结结巴巴地说道。”这是不是你的球，居然拿到教室里来胡作非为!"黄老师平静的说道，心里想着：希望他们承认错误，我还是不会骂他的。“没有，根本没有，我以偷篮球的技术来担保，啊呸呸呸，我有证人，那就是小明！”大华一口气说道。“对......对吧。“小明结结巴巴地说道。老师故意没说，却说”那么你们当时在不在玩这个篮球呢？“黄老师服满疑问的问道。”没有，就算有一百个摄像头看着我，也不可能会发现一点证据呢！”大华再一次的狡辩道。“嗯......没有吧。“小明又结结巴巴地说道。“真的，我再问一遍，这是不是你的球，居然拿到教室里来胡作非为！你们当时在不在玩这个篮球呢？你承认我就不会骂你，也不会责怪你的！“黄老师平静地说，但是小明和大华一一摇头。大华坚决地摇头，但是小明只是微微摇头，不过还带了点颤抖。
 黄老师没办法，只好先送哪位小朋友到医务室，接着带着大华和小明上到四楼。”我们要去哪里呀？“小明问道，“我也不知道。“大华回答道，他们转过一个又一个走廊终于到达了，房间外的字使他们毛骨悚然，而那字是”校长室“。黄老师没有直接带他们进去，却又问了一遍之前的问题”这是不是你的球，居然拿到教室里来，你们当时在不在玩这个篮球吗？“ 这次大华居然畏畏缩缩地说”这......这个球是我从体育库里偷......偷来的，当时是......是在跟小明玩球。“
 黄老师平静地说到”你们承认了错误，值得表扬，我可以原谅你们，但是你们所做的行为是不能宽恕的，你们这一周都不能再课间休息时玩。“，”知道了！我们保证下一次不会再犯同样的错误了。“小明和大华异口同声地说道。接着，老师让他们回去，他们回到教室，跟那个打到的小朋友说了道歉，一后再也没有偷过东西，也没有在教室里玩了。
 所谓”前事不忘，后事之师。“以后我们做错了事，要承认错误，这样能受到原谅。但是我们不能一而三再而三的犯了，不能做一个屡教不改的孩子哦！

column4:
Write a composition of at least 150 words on what you can do to make a difference.

.
column5:
"That's it. That dog has to go. I'm sick and tired of it destroying the things in the
 house, especially the shoes!"
"But..." Danny
I tried to interject.
"No 'but'!" his mother stormed. Danny's mother had ranted and raved about this before. However, this time, I detected the steely tone in her voice. Before long, it spelt doom for me.
Soon, I would be separated from Danny, my optimistic, fun-loving master whom I adored with all my doggy heart. Danny was protesting, tears glazing his eyes. His mother’s voice had now risen to fever pitch. What was I to do? I knew I had tried to behave. Well, except for one thing — I had the habit of chewing things.

 I flattened my body on the floor, laid my head on my paws and whined. I looked at him mournfully. My legs had turned into mush because of the fear that seized my heart.
“I’m taking him for a walk,” Danny muttered, blinking away unshed tears.
Walking beside Danny, birds flew free in the sky and chirped aloud their cheeky calls. It was an idyllic scene.
“Danny!” someone yelled. It was Mother’s close friend. She was out walking with a baby in a pram.
“Hi, Mrs. Deepak!” Danny shouted as he ran up the slope towards her. As she chatted with Danny, she rocked the pram gently to soothe the baby.
Suddenly, my hackles rose with a tingling premonition. 
 A little boy on a bicycle swerved past unsteadily and knocked Mrs. Deepak's arm. She lost her grip on the pram, and it went rolling down the slope with the baby still inside. I caught a glimpse of the look of horror on her face, as if it had been etched on white marble. My canine instincts had proven right. With a loud bark, I bounded forward, jerking the lead out of Danny's hands in that split second. The lead streamed behind me as I raced after the runaway pram. With an extra burst of energy, I shot level with the pram. Snapping my jaws over one side of the handlebar, I dug into the ground with my paws. The pram's momentum dragged me a little, but to my utmost relief, the wheels slowed, then halted entirely. 
Mrs. Deepak rushed over, her trembling hands scooping the unharmed baby from the pram. Danny caught up, breathless, and clipped my lead back on. "Good boy!" he panted, ruffling my fur. Mrs. Deepak thanked me with tearful eyes, and I wagged my tail—just another day in the life of a dog who’d finally earned his extra-large biscuit.
 To my utmost relief, it stopped safely. Surprisingly, the baby was gurgling. Running feet pounded up as Mrs. Deepak dashed to pick up her baby, Danny right on her heels. "Oh, Danny! Your wonderful dog saved my baby!" Mrs. Deepak repeated, clasping the baby to her bosom. Later, I learned Danny had poured out his woes to her earlier. That was why she insisted on accompanying him home to speak to his mother about me. When Danny’s mother looked at me, I responded with a bark. Her eyes softened, and she agreed I deserved a second chance. I was allowed to stay! 

A week later, Mrs. Deepak gifted me a gnawing bone shaped like a pair of shoes to show her gratitude. It even tasted like shoes! My act of heroism paid off, and peace finally reigned in the household.

"No 'but'!" his mother stormed. Danny's mother had ranted and raved about this before. However, this time, I detected the steely tone in her voice. Before long, it spelt doom for me.
Soon, I would be separated from Danny, my optimistic, fun-loving master whom I adored with all my doggy heart. Danny was protesting, tears glazing his eyes. His mother’s voice had now risen to fever pitch. What was I to do? I knew I had tried to behave. Well, except for one thing — I had the habit of chewing things.

 I flattened my body on the floor, laid my head on my paws and whined. I looked at him mournfully. My legs had turned into mush because of the fear that seized my heart.
“I’m taking him for a walk,” Danny muttered, blinking away unshed tears.
Walking beside Danny, birds flew free in the sky and chirped aloud their cheeky calls. It was an idyllic scene.
“Danny!” someone yelled. It was Mother’s close friend. She was out walking with a baby in a pram.
“Hi, Mrs. Deepak!” Danny shouted as he ran up the slope towards her. As she chatted with Danny, she rocked the pram gently to soothe the baby.
Suddenly, my hackles rose with a tingling premonition. 
 A little boy on a bicycle swerved past unsteadily and knocked Mrs. Deepak's arm. She lost her grip on the pram, and it went rolling down the slope with the baby still inside. I caught a glimpse of the look of horror on her face, as if it had been etched on white marble. My canine instincts had proven right. With a loud bark, I bounded forward, jerking the lead out of Danny's hands in that split second. The lead streamed behind me as I raced after the runaway pram. With an extra burst of energy, I shot level with the pram. Snapping my jaws over one side of the handlebar, I dug into the ground with my paws. The pram's momentum dragged me a little, but to my utmost relief, the wheels slowed, then halted entirely. 
Mrs. Deepak rushed over, her trembling hands scooping the unharmed baby from the pram. Danny caught up, breathless, and clipped my lead back on. "Good boy!" he panted, ruffling my fur. Mrs. Deepak thanked me with tearful eyes, and I wagged my tail—just another day in the life of a dog who’d finally earned his extra-large biscuit.
 To my utmost relief, it stopped safely. Surprisingly, the baby was gurgling. Running feet pounded up as Mrs. Deepak dashed to pick up her baby, Danny right on her heels. "Oh, Danny! Your wonderful dog saved my baby!" Mrs. Deepak repeated, clasping the baby to her bosom. Later, I learned Danny had poured out his woes to her earlier. That was why she insisted on accompanying him home to speak to his mother about me. When Danny’s mother looked at me, I responded with a bark. Her eyes softened, and she agreed I deserved a second chance. I was allowed to stay! 

A week later, Mrs. Deepak gifted me a gnawing bone shaped like a pair of shoes to show her gratitude. It even tasted like shoes! My act of heroism paid off, and peace finally reigned in the household.

column4:
请写一篇不少过100个字的作文。作文的题目是《发生在上学路上的一件事》。

.\n
column5:
一个乌云密布的下午小安放完学再回家的路，上突然碰到了一位年轻人。他忽然脚滑了一下，没来得及站稳就撞上那位年轻人了。年轻人摇晃了一下，手里的手机掉到了草丛里面差点摔坏了。
 小安看到了眼前的情景呆住了，他傻傻的站在那里，不知道怎么办才好。年轻人录取匆匆的对小安喊道：＂放学了，跑这么快干嘛？＂小安被这位年轻人吓得瑟瑟发抖，他结结巴巴地说：＂我我……我刚刚没注意到你不小心撞到你了，对不起。＂
 年轻人说：＂以后注意一点，下雨天不要跑这样很容易发生意外，还好手机掉到草丛里面了，要不然就摔坏了。＂小安说：知道了，以后我不会跑的。＂

column4:
What are FTAs? How does FTAs enable economic cooperation?
.\n
column5: FTAs, or Free Trade Agreements, are treaties between two or more countries to reduce or eliminate trade barriers like tariffs and quotas, facilitating trade and investment. This enables economic cooperation by fostering increased trade, lower costs, and access to new markets, ultimately promoting economic growth and development.
column7: FTA stands for Free Trade Agreements. By engaging in free trade, countires can choose to cooperate wtih other countries.

column4:
What are FTAs? How does FTAs enable economic cooperation?
.\n
column5: FTAs, or Free Trade Agreements, are treaties between two or more countries to reduce or eliminate trade barriers like tariffs and quotas, facilitating trade and investment. .\n
column5: 对家庭而言，沟通更是必不可少。现今社会生活节奏快，很多人早出晚归，终日忙碌，很少和家人沟通，以致与家人的关系渐渐疏远。比如，我们常常看到这样的情景：父亲工作一天回到家，累得只想刷手机放松，孩子想分享学校的趣事，却只得到父亲心不在焉的回应；或者母亲忙于家务，孩子几次想帮忙或倾诉烦恼，都被母亲以“别捣乱”或“等一下再说”打发掉。一次两次或许没什么，但长此以往，孩子会觉得父母并不关心自己的生活和感受，便渐渐不再主动与父母交流。父母也可能因不了解孩子的内心世界，在教育上产生误解和冲突。其实，即使亲如家人，也需要经常交流。这样一来，孩子会更体恤父母的辛劳，父母会更了解孩子的心思，家庭氛围也会因此变得更加融洽。
column6: Provide specific text replacement for students to improve the text.
column7:
• 对家庭而言，沟通更是必不可少。现今社会生活节奏快，很多人早出晚归，终日忙碌，很少和家人沟通，以致与家人的关系渐渐疏远。其实，即使亲如家人，也需要经常交流。这样一来，孩子会更体恤父母的辛劳，父母会更了解孩子的心思，家庭氛围也会因此变得更加融洽。心理学家维吉尼亚·萨提尔说：“家庭沟通的方式，决定了一个孩子未来与世界沟通的方式。”可见，良好的家庭沟通对孩子的成长影响深远。如果家长平时能以耐心和关怀倾听孩子的烦恼，孩子便能在被理解的过程中建立自信，也更愿意表达自己。在这样的互动中，孩子学会如何与人相处、表达情感和解决问题，为将来融入社会打下良好基础。相反，如果家庭缺乏沟通，孩子容易感到孤单、不被重视，甚至发展出冷漠或逆反的性格。因此，一个懂得倾听与交流的家庭，不仅能建立亲情，还能塑造健全的人格。

  • 对家庭而言，沟通更是必不可少。现今社会生活节奏快，很多人早出晚归，终日忙碌，很少和家人沟通，以致与家人的关系渐渐疏远。其实，即使亲如家人，也需要经常交流。这样一来，孩子会更体恤父母的辛劳，父母会更了解孩子的心思，家庭氛围也会因此变得更加融洽。根据新加坡家庭服务中心的一项调查，超过六成的问题青少年来自沟通不足或关系紧张的家庭环境。研究也指出，亲子之间若能保持稳定沟通，青少年的心理健康水平和自信心更高，出现行为偏差的几率也明显较低。这些数据清楚地显示，有效的家庭沟通不仅能改善亲子关系，也在孩子的情绪发展与行为表现上发挥关键作用。

• 对家庭而言，沟通更是必不可少。现今社会生活节奏快，很多人早出晚归，终日忙碌，很少和家人沟通，以致与家人的关系渐渐疏远。其实，即使亲如家人，也需要经常交流。这样一来，孩子会更体恤父母的辛劳，父母会更了解孩子的心思，家庭氛围也会因此变得更加融洽。心理学家维吉尼亚·萨提尔说：“家庭沟通的方式，决定了一个孩子未来与世界沟通的方式。”可见，良好的家庭沟通对孩子的成长影响深远。如果家长平时能以耐心和关怀倾听孩子的烦恼，孩子便能在被理解的过程中建立自信，也更愿意表达自己。在这样的互动中，孩子学会如何与人相处、表达情感和解决问题，为将来融入社会打下良好基础。相反，如果家庭缺乏沟通，孩子容易感到孤单、不被重视，甚至发展出冷漠或逆反的性格。因此，一个懂得倾听与交流的家庭，不仅能建立亲情，还能塑造健全的人格。

  • 对家庭而言，沟通更是必不可少。现今社会生活节奏快，很多人早出晚归，终日忙碌，很少和家人沟通，以致与家人的关系渐渐疏远。其实，即使亲如家人，也需要经常交流。这样一来，孩子会更体恤父母的辛劳，父母会更了解孩子的心思，家庭氛围也会因此变得更加融洽。根据新加坡家庭服务中心的一项调查，超过六成的问题青少年来自沟通不足或关系紧张的家庭环境。研究也指出，亲子之间若能保持稳定沟通，青少年的心理健康水平和自信心更高，出现行为偏差的几率也明显较低。这些数据清楚地显示，有效的家庭沟通不仅能改善亲子关系，也在孩子的情绪发展与行为表现上发挥关键作用。

.\n
column5: 对家庭而言，沟通更是必不可少。现今社会生活节奏快，很多人早出晚归，终日忙碌，很少和家人沟通，以致与家人的关系渐渐疏远。比如，我们常常看到这样的情景：父亲工作一天回到家，累得只想刷手机放松，孩子想分享学校的趣事，却只得到父亲心不在焉的回应；或者母亲忙于家务，孩子几次想帮忙或倾诉烦恼，都被母亲以“别捣乱”或“等一下再说”打发掉。一次两次或许没什么，但长此以往，孩子会觉得父母并不关心自己的生活和感受，便渐渐不再主动与父母交流。父母也可能因不了解孩子的内心世界，在教育上产生误解和冲突。其实，即使亲如家人，也需要经常交流。这样一来，孩子会更体恤父母的辛劳，父母会更了解孩子的心思，家庭氛围也会因此变得更加融洽。

column4:
1. A Fearful Encounter

Scenario: You were walking home alone after your CCA ended late. Suddenly, you heard footsteps behind you…

 

Instructions:
Write a short paragraph describing the fearful encounter. Include:

  • What led up to the moment

  • What you saw, heard, or felt

  • How you reacted

  • How the situation ended

Tips:

  • Build suspense with short sentences.

  • Use sensory details (e.g. footsteps, shadows, cold wind).

  • Show your emotions clearly.

.
column5:
**A Fearful Encounter**
It was already past 8 p.m. when my CCA finally ended. The sky was an inky blue, and the streetlights cast long, flickering shadows on the pavement. My bag felt heavy on my shoulders, and the usually familiar walk home seemed eerily quiet. I was the last one to leave school, and the silence made my footsteps sound louder than usual.
As I turned down the narrow lane that led to my block, I suddenly heard it — footsteps. Slow. Deliberate. Just behind me.
At first, I thought it was my imagination. I quickened my pace slightly, and the footsteps did too. A chill ran down my spine. I dared not look back. My heart began to pound, and my breaths came faster.
*Who could it be? Why were they following me?* 
I reached into my pocket for my phone, but my hands were trembling. The footsteps grew louder, quicker. I turned a sharp corner and broke into a run. My bag thumped against my back as I sprinted towards the main road, where I knew there would be people.
Then I heard a voice behind me, breathless. “Wait! You dropped this!”
I stopped in my tracks and spun around. A boy, around my age, was holding my water bottle. I had left it on the bench outside the school gate. His eyes widened in alarm, realizing he had frightened me.
“I’m so sorry!” he said, holding up both hands in surrender. “I didn’t mean to scare you—I just wanted to return this.”
Relief flooded through me, mixed with embarrassment. I took the bottle and mumbled a thank you, still catching my breath. The fear that had gripped me moments ago faded, replaced by laughter — nervous, but genuine.
It was a fearful encounter, yes — but also a reminder that sometimes, our minds can turn shadows into monsters.
column6: Provide subtle hints or clues without giving direct answers, allowing students to arrive at the correct answer on their own.
column7:
div class="paragraph">

The sky had already turned dark when I left the school gate. The usually busy road was quiet, and even the coffeeshop at the corner was closing. As I walked past the playground, I heard soft footsteps behind me. I stopped. The footsteps stopped too. I turned around quickly, but the path was empty.

 

My heart pounded. I quickened my pace, clutching my bag tightly. The sound came again, louder this time. Was someone following me? I remembered the stories my friends had told about this area being haunted. Just then, a cat dashed across the road. I gasped.

 

To my great relief, it was just a stray cat knocking over a rubbish bin. I laughed nervously at myself. Maybe I had watched too many horror movies.

column5:
**A Fearful Encounter**
It was already past 8 p.m. when my CCA finally ended. The sky was an inky blue, and the streetlights cast long, flickering shadows on the pavement. My bag felt heavy on my shoulders, and the usually familiar walk home seemed eerily quiet. I was the last one to leave school, and the silence made my footsteps sound louder than usual.
As I turned down the narrow lane that led to my block, I suddenly heard it — footsteps. Slow. Deliberate. Just behind me.
At first, I thought it was my imagination. I quickened my pace slightly, and the footsteps did too. A chill ran down my spine. I dared not look back. My heart began to pound, and my breaths came faster.
*Who could it be? Why were they following me?* 
I reached into my pocket for my phone, but my hands were trembling. The footsteps grew louder, quicker. I turned a sharp corner and broke into a run. My bag thumped against my back as I sprinted towards the main road, where I knew there would be people.
Then I heard a voice behind me, breathless. “Wait! You dropped this!”
I stopped in my tracks and spun around. A boy, around my age, was holding my water bottle. I had left it on the bench outside the school gate. His eyes widened in alarm, realizing he had frightened me.
“I’m so sorry!” he said, holding up both hands in surrender. “I didn’t mean to scare you—I just wanted to return this.”
Relief flooded through me, mixed with embarrassment. I took the bottle and mumbled a thank you, still catching my breath. The fear that had gripped me moments ago faded, replaced by laughter — nervous, but genuine.
It was a fearful encounter, yes — but also a reminder that sometimes, our minds can turn shadows into monsters.
column6: Provide subtle hints or clues without giving direct answers, allowing students to arrive at the correct answer on their own.
column7:
div class="paragraph">

The sky had already turned dark when I left the school gate. The usually busy road was quiet, and even the coffeeshop at the corner was closing. As I walked past the playground, I heard soft footsteps behind me. I stopped. The footsteps stopped too. I turned around quickly, but the path was empty.

 

My heart pounded. I quickened my pace, clutching my bag tightly. The sound came again, louder this time. Was someone following me? I remembered the stories my friends had told about this area being haunted. Just then, a cat dashed across the road. I gasped.

 

To my great relief, it was just a stray cat knocking over a rubbish bin. I laughed nervously at myself. Maybe I had watched too many horror movies.

column4:
1. A Fearful Encounter

Scenario: You were walking home alone after your CCA ended late. Suddenly, you heard footsteps behind you…

 

Instructions:
Write a short paragraph describing the fearful encounter. Include:

  • What led up to the moment

  • What you saw, heard, or felt

  • How you reacted

  • How the situation ended

Tips:

  • Build suspense with short sentences.

  • Use sensory details (e.g. footsteps, shadows, cold wind).

  • Show your emotions clearly.

.

column4:
Explain why a fuse is included in the circuit and explain what happens when the fuse blows.
.\n
column5: The fuse prevents excessive current from causing fires. When there is too much current flowing through, the fuse will heat up and melt, which will cause the circuit to be opened and the appliance to stop functioning until the fuse is replaced.\n
column6: Provide subtle hints or clues without giving direct answers, allowing students to arrive at the correct answer on their own.
column7:
A fuse protects the circuit by [preventing excessive current flow].
\n
When a [large current] flows through the fuse, it [heats up and melts].
\n
It creates an [open circuit and stops current flowing through the circuit].

column6: Provide subtle hints or clues without giving direct answers, allowing students to arrive at the correct answer on their own.
column7:
A fuse protects the circuit by [preventing excessive current flow].
\n
When a [large current] flows through the fuse, it [heats up and melts].
\n
It creates an [open circuit and stops current flowing through the circuit].
